name: Abietic acid
background_info: The pure material is almost white, crystalline plates or powder. Melting point: 174-182°C. Lower-grade commercial material is usually off-white or pale straw-colored, with granular crystals or a conglomerated mass that has a much lower melting point. Insoluble in water, it is soluble in alcohol and oils. It is also soluble in an aqueous solution of sodium hydroxide. The pure material is virtually odorless, while the commercial material has a faint, pleasant resinous odor. Abietic acid is slightly bitter at concentrations of more than 50 ppm. It is also the natural source and parent of several solvent-fixatives used in perfumery: Abitol, Methyl Abietate (Abalyn), and hydrogenated Methyl Abietate (Hercolyn). Rosin, the natural material, is occasionally used as a fixative in Pine and other fragrance types. It is inexpensive and has, at times, been popular in certain types of soap perfume. Certain derivatives of Abietic acid are used as emulsifiers and 'cloudifiers' in carbonated beverages to give the visual impression of fruit juice content in drinks made with little or no 'cloudy' natural juice. 'Cloudy' orange sodas are popular in certain countries. Production: By distillation of rosin (e.g., from American turpentine) or by treatment with acid to isomerize the natural levopimaric acid. Purification is done using the diamylammonium salt. Molecular Weight: 302.46

name: Abitol
background_info: Hydroabietyl Alcohol (technical grade. A primary monohydric alcohol consisting approximately of: 38% Tetrahydroabietyl alcohol (1) 34% Dihydroabietyl alcohol (2) 13% Dehydroabietyl alcohol (3) 15% Non-alcoholic components Colorless, tacky-viscous liquid, non-pourable at room temperature. Specific Gravity (Sp. Gr.): 1.01 Insoluble in water, but miscible with alcohol, terpenes, essential oils, and most perfume chemicals. Very faint, woody, and slightly piney odor. Intermittent heating may cause an increase in the odor level. An excellent fixative for low-cost fragrances of pine, wood, fougère, new-mown hay, and other types. Suitable for industrial fragrances, household products, soap perfumes, etc. Produced from hydrogenated rosin acids. Molecular Weight: 292.51

name: Ambrein
background_info: A Terpenoid Tertiary Alcohol. Do not confuse with the 'Ambrein' derived from Labdanum gum. This material is briefly mentioned in this work because it represents a milestone in perfume chemistry research (connected with Vitamin and Hormone research). It may also help further elucidate monographs and materials mentioned under the titles: Sclareol or Abietic acid. Ambrein is an odorless solid material, but it serves as the parent of numerous very important ambergris perfume materials, including those found in nature. Oxidation products of Ambrein have been manufactured, opening the door to the partial synthesis of the ambergris odor. One commercial product, Ambrone T or Ambrone Clair (Takasago Perfumery Co. Ltd., Japan), is produced through ozonolysis of odorless Ambrein and concentration of the odorous, volatile oxidation products. Since natural ambergris contains substantial amounts of odorless Ambrein, the ozonolysis method increases the yield of perfume-grade odorous ambergris material. Mother Nature’s incomplete synthesis has been completed by human innovation. Among the odorous derivatives of Ambrein are: Ambrenolide (Lactones, C₁₆H₂₄O₂) Decalin derivatives Ambrenols - liquid or solid, tertiary alcohols (Octalin derivatives) Cyclohomogeraniol and related materials Dihydro-gamma-ionone Cyclopropan derivatives Various epoxides and aldehydes. Molecular Weight: 428.75

name: Ambrinol
background_info:
Ambrinol or Ambrenols
A group of isomeric Octalin derivatives with the general formula and structure:
2,5,5-Trimethyl-2-hydroxy-octalin.

Isomers with unsaturation (double bond) in positions 8,9 or 1,9 are the three materials of particular interest to perfumery. These are colorless liquids or white solid materials with a melting point of 60–70°C.

The title materials are briefly mentioned in this work because of their potential interest to the perfumer. They are natural components of ambergris and are considered of major importance to the olfactory properties of natural ambergris and ambergris tincture.

Although these materials have been synthesized and also obtained as isolates from natural ambergris, they are not yet commercially available under the name Ambrinol. Closely related chemicals are synthesized at lower cost but lack the same attractive olfactory effect.

The eye-catching structural similarity between Ambrinols and Ambrein, Sclareol, Abietic acid, Dihydro-gamma-ionone, etc., has been the subject of much discussion in modern perfumery literature.

When the title materials become commercially available at an attractive price, they will undoubtedly find their way into perfumery, contributing to amber bases, new perfume types, and specialties. Certain specialties already partly incorporate the title materials. Molecular Weight: 194.32

name: alpha-n-Butyl-gamma-Butyrolactone
background_info:
An Isomer of Octalactone
This chemical is not identical with the one known as gamma-iso-Octalactone.

Physical Properties:

Colorless oily liquid
Practically insoluble in water, but soluble in alcohol and most perfume and flavor materials
Boiling Point (B.P.): 230°C
Specific Gravity (Sp. Gr.): 0.98
Samples of the material have shown considerable variation in odor, leading the author to believe that other isomers may be present in varying proportions.

The classical odor description—Cumin, Anise, and Ambergris—is somewhat vague and does not fully capture the material's scent, whether pure or contaminated. By omitting the Cumin and Anise notes, the Ambergris nuance may be more perceptible to most observers. The condiment-like or spicy sweet note resembles Caraway but is much softer, with a Coconut-like background.

This lactone has been suggested for use in perfumes and flavors, but the author is not aware of any significant applications in such products. Furthermore, it does not appear on price lists from regular suppliers of rare perfume and flavor chemicals.

Production:
Produced by various methods, e.g., from n-Butyl malonic ester and Ethylene oxide. Molecular Weight: 142.20

name: alpha-Cedrene epoxide
background_info:
Blends excellently with Oakmoss, Methylionones (particularly the so-called delta-Methylionone or iso-Methyl beta-Ionone), Labdanum extracts, Methylcoumarins, and similar materials.

Chemical perfumery research has long focused on 'Oxides' or Epoxides. These compounds are of great interest in perfume chemistry, with many examples of terpenes and their corresponding epoxides holding significance:

Carene → Epoxycarene
Caryophyllene → Epoxydihydrocaryophyllene
Pinene → Pinol
Menthane → Cineole
Not to mention the epoxides related to certain alcohols, such as Linalool oxide and Rose oxide.

Physical Properties:

Colorless viscous liquid
Insoluble in water, but soluble in alcohol and perfume oils
Odor Profile:
A dry-woody yet very pleasant odor with a certain sweetness in its undertone. The combination of dry and sweet notes is rare, found only in a few natural wood oils, ambergris, and certain herbaceous extracts.

Molecular Weight: 220.36

name: Cedryl formate
background_info:
C₁₆H₂₆O₂

Physical Properties:

Colorless oily liquid
Practically insoluble in water
Soluble in alcohol and miscible with oils
Odor Profile:
A mild but persistent dry-woody odor. The woody notes are accompanied by a discrete greenness, creating an ensemble reminiscent of certain aspects of the ambergris odor profile.

Applications:
Recommended for use in perfume compositions, particularly in combination with:

Ionones
Rose bases
Modern aldehydic bases
Newer versions of 'men's fragrances,' often in combination with lime materials
Undoubtedly cleaner than Cedryl acetate, this formate may find a place in the perfume laboratory of modern and unconventional creative perfumers.

Molecular Weight: 238.37

name: Clovene
background_info:
C₁₅H₂₄O

Physical Properties:

Colorless, oily, slightly viscous liquid
Specific Gravity (Sp.Gr.): 0.93
Boiling Point (B.P.): 261–263°C
Insoluble in water, soluble in alcohol and oils
Odor Profile:
A dry-woody, spicy odor, remotely reminiscent of the dry notes of ambergris (Ambra) and leather. It has good tenacity.

Applications:
Suggested for use as a blender-fixative in:

Men's fragrances of the Leather and Amber types
Citrus colognes
Lavender-Citrus types
Certain types of women’s fragrances where very dry notes are desirable, such as alongside Galbanum, Oakmoss, Vetiver acetate, 'gamma' Methylionone, etc.
Production:
Produced by dehydration of beta-Caryophyllene alcohol, which is obtained from Clove Caryophyllenes through cyclization with mineral acid.

Molecular Weight: 204.36

name: gamma-Cyclo-homogeraniol
background_info:
1,1-Dimethyl-2(beta-hydroxyethyl)-3-methylenecyclohexane,
2-(6,6-Dimethyl-2-methylene)-cyclohexylethanol

Physical Properties:

Colorless oily liquid
Practically insoluble in water
Soluble in alcohol and oils
Odor Profile:
A powerful, sweet ambergris-type odor with moderate to good tenacity. This material contributes to the very desirable 'maritime' odor of ambergris.

Applications:
The 'seashore' type odor has long been a challenge for perfumers aiming to introduce a 'novel' note instead of using materials like Oakmoss. While Nerol has been used to imitate the seashore-type odor, it captures only a modest part of that olfactory picture.

The title material has been manufactured synthetically but is not yet offered commercially under its proper chemical name. It is used in bases and specialties that evoke an ambergris-type odor.

Molecular Weight: 168.28

name: Decahydro-beta-naphtaldehyde
background_info:
Exists in cis- and trans-forms
Commercial material is mostly the trans-isomer.

Physical Properties:

Colorless oily liquid
Boiling Point (B.P.): 233°C
Almost insoluble in water
Soluble in alcohol and oils
Odor Profile:
A peculiar dry, musty, powerful odor reminiscent of certain notes found in ambergris.

Applications:
Used in perfume compositions to support ambergris notes, whether natural or synthetic.

Production:
Produced from beta-Decalone with sodium and ethyl chloroacetate, followed by saponification of the glycidate.

Molecular Weight: 166.27
